sections.text: Variables are containers for storing data values.

sections.subtitle: Creating Variables
sections.text:
Python has no command for declaring a variable.
A variable is created the moment you first assign a value to it.
Variables do not need to be declared with any particular type, and can even change type after they have been set.

sections.subtitle: Example
sections.text:
x = 4       # x is of type int
x = "Sally" # x is now of type str
print(x)

sections.subtitle: Casting
sections.text: If you want to specify the data type of a variable, this can be done with casting.

sections.subtitle: Example
sections.text:
x = str(3)    # x will be '3'
y = int(3)    # y will be 3
z = float(3)  # z will be 3.0

sections.subtitle: Get the Type
sections.text: You can get the data type of a variable with the type() function.

sections.subtitle: Example
sections.text:
x = 5
y = "Hello World"
print(type(x))
print(type(y))

You will learn more about data types and casting later in this tutorial.

sections.subtitle: Single or Double Quotes?
sections.text: String variables can be declared either by using single or double quotes:

sections.subtitle: Example
sections.text:
x = "John"
# is the same as
x = 'John'

sections.subtitle: Example
sections.text:
This will create two variables:
a = 4
A = "Sally"
#A will not overwrite a
